items.message: The flood forecast has changed significantly. As a result, there is no longer a risk of flooding in the area.

items.description: River Foulness and Market Weighton catchment

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Foulness, Market Weighton Canal, North Cave Beck, Ellerker Beck, Mill Beck

items.message: There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.

Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels remain high on the Upper River Wey, especially in the Passfield Mill and Godalming areas, as a result of recent heavy rainfall.  Therefore, flooding of roads and low lying land is expected to continue today (19/11/2022). It is forecast to be a mainly dry day 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England's webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated this evening, 19/11/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high but steady at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road. No further significant rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to remain high until tomorrow evening, 20/11/2022. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 21:00 this evening, 19/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels remain high on the Chertsey Bourne, especially in the Free Prae Road area, as a result of recent heavy rainfall.  Therefore, flooding of roads and low lying land is expected to continue today (19/11/2022). It is forecast to be a mainly dry day.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England's webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated this evening, 19/11/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high but steady at the Willington Cableway and Shardlow river gauges as a result of persistent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue today, 19/11/22 and over the next few days. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Willington, Barrow upon Trent, Swarkestone, Bargate Lane and the access roads to Willington Meadows, the Twyford Village access road, Church Lane at Barrow, and Ingleby Lane. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 17:00 today, 19/11/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message: This Flood Alert has been removed.  River and high tide levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.

items.description: River Wiske and tributaries to the River Swale

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Wiske, Brompton Beck, Cod Beck, North Beck, Willow Beck, Sun Beck, Winton Beck

items.message: River levels are forecast to rise on the Brompton Beck, Cod Beck, River Wiske, and Willow Beck due to a combination of rainfall on Thursday and high levels on the River Swale. Low lying land is expected to be most affected, particularly around the River Wiske around Kirby Wiske, Brompton Beck, Cod Beck, North Beck, Willow Beck, Sun Beck, and Winton Beck today, through Saturday 19/11/2022. Saturday is expected to be largely dry, although river levels will remain high. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 9:00 PM on 19/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

The flood alert for the River Rye catchment remains in force. River levels are remaining high on the River Rye catchment due to rainfall over the last few days. Flooding of land is still possible on land around the River Rye and its tributaries, including Ralsdale Beck, River Seph, Ledge Beck, Fangdale Beck, Prodale Beck, Ladhill Beck, Etton Gill, Borough Beck and Spittle Beck, including at Salton, Nunnington and Helmsley. River levels around Ness and Nunnington have fallen, but are forecast to rise again late on Saturday morning, 19/11/2022 following some localised rainfall. No further significant rainfall is forecast for Saturday. We will continue to monitor levels closely. This message will be updated by 09:00 PM on 19/11/2022, or earlier if the situation changes.

items.description: River Erewash in Derbyshire and Nottinghamshire
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
      
We continue to monitor the situation.

River levels are continuing to fall at the Eathorpe river gauge following the rain earlier in the week.  Consequently, the risk of flooding is reducing.  Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Leam between Grandborough and Leamington including Kites Hardwick, Birdingbury, Marton, Eathorpe, Hunningham and Offchurch and the River Itchen between Southam and Marton including Long Itchington.    
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 to 48 hours.  
We are closely monitoring the situation and our incident response staff are clearing weed screens.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and stay aware in case further warnings are issued.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 20/11/22, or as the situation changes.

The flood alert for the River Seven catchment remains in force as river levels remain high around Normanby due to persistent heavy rainfall over the last few days. Flooding remains possible on land around the River Seven and its tributaries including Northdale Beck, Hartoft Beck, Ings Beck, Lastingham Beck, Sutherland Beck, Cropton Beck and Catter Beck, and to the East of Normanby. River levels around Sinnington and Normanby have fallen, but are forecast to rise again late on Saturday morning, 19/11/2022 following some localised rainfall this morning. No further significant rainfall is forecast for Saturday. We will continue to monitor levels closely. This message will be updated by 09:00 PM on 19/11/2022, or as the situation changes.
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.

The high water levels in the Eastern Yar, continue to fall slowly. At Alverstone, the river level is decreasing by approximately 1cm per hour but is now below the level of flood risk to property. Likewise, the level at Sandown is decreasing at approximately 1cm per hour, however, Fort Holiday Park will continue to be affected through the next 24 hours. At Bembridge, channels will struggle to drain into the marsh while water levels remain high, especially over high tide. We are operating Bembridge sluice to manage the water level at Brading marshes. No rain is forecast for the remainder of Saturday (19/11/22), however the weather becomes unsettled from early Sunday morning (20/11/22). The current forecast suggests through Monday (21/11/22) into Tuesday morning (22/11/22) could see up to 40mm of rain. If realised, this would likely see flood warnings issued again for the upper and lower Eastern Yar catchment. We will continue to monitor the river and weather forecast information. Avoid walking or driving through flood water. This Flood Alert will be updated by 14:00 on Sunday 20/11/22.

items.description: River Blackwater and The Cove Brook
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed. 
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. The forecast for the next few days is for mostly dry weather.
We continue to monitor the situation, and will re-issue this alert if necessary.

The River Ouse is still high but is slowly falling. Water will remain in fields and on rural roads. Very little rainfall is forecast for Saturday, which should allow the River Ouse to return nearer to a normal level by Sunday. Another 10-40mm of rain Sunday and Monday could cause flood risk to return next week. Some roads affected by flooding could still be impassable, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding including Barcombe Mills Road, Fletching Mill Bridge and Sharpsbridge. We are operating our structures at Pimms Lock and Barcombe to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk.

The Cuckmere River is still high, but is slowly falling. Minor flood impacts may continue to affect North Street, Litlington Road, Willows Car Park, River Lane, The Old Clergy House and Deans Place Hotel, Alfriston. The Cuckmere and Bull Rivers in Hellingly have fallen significantly from their peak and only minimal flood impacts are expected in Hellingly. Very little rainfall is forecast Saturday. The Cuckmere River in Alfriston will continue to fall, but river levels are unlikely to return nearer to normal until Sunday (20/11/2022). Another 10-40mm of rain Sunday and Monday could cause more flood risk next week. Please plan to avoid driving through routes susceptible to flooding, including North Street Alfriston.

items.message: This Flood Alert remains in force following heavy rain across Kent earlier in the week. River levels in the River Medway and its tributaries are falling significantly this morning from Yalding to Maidstone. Flooding of low lying land and towpaths is however likely to continue into this afternoon, Saturday 19 November. This Flood Alert is likely to be removed later today. Further periods of heavy rainfall are forecast from tomorrow, Sunday 20 November and throughout next week. We will continue to monitor the situation closely.

There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.
No further rainfall is forecast.
River levels are falling.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away.

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed. 
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. The forecast for the next few days is for mostly dry weather.
We continue to monitor the situation, and will re-issue this alert if necessary.

The Western Rother is still high but is slowly falling. Minor flood impacts may continue to affect properties at Lodsbridge and Fittleworth and surrounding fields, rural roads and gardens in those locations. Between Liss and Midhurst, river levels have already fallen significantly from their peak with only minimal flood impacts expected there. Very little rainfall is forecast Saturday. River levels will remain higher than normal in Fittleworth until Sunday. Another 10-40mm of rain Sunday and Monday could cause more flood risk next week. Please keep flood protection products installed in Lodsbridge and Fittleworth. Please plan to avoid driving through roads prone to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will re-issue this message if the risk of flooding increases again.

River levels remain high but steady on the River Roding at Abridge and Loughton. There is a risk of flooding to roads and low lying land due to high river levels throughout today, Saturday 19 November, as the river continues to respond to recent heavy rain.
The dry weather today will allow the river level to slowly fall. However, it is expected to remain high throughout the day and further rain is forecast for the coming days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages and clearing debris from structures.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and remain aware of the weather forecast. 

This message will be updated this evening, Saturday 19 November, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed. 
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. The forecast for the next few days is for mostly dry weather.
We continue to monitor the situation, and will re-issue this alert if necessary.

The Aldingbourne Rife is high but has now peaked and will slowly fall through Saturday. Flooding will continue to affect fields near Shripney Lane and the A259, parts of the car park at Tesco and land around caravans at Riverside Caravan Centre and Rowan Park Caravan Park. Very little rainfall is forecast Saturday. The river should continue to fall through Saturday but will remain higher than normal until next week. In Barnham, river levels are already significantly lower than their peak and falling. Any minor flood impacts in Barnham should reduce. Another 10-40mm of rain Sunday and Monday could cause more flood risk next week. Some roads, including Shripney Lane may be impassable, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We routinely clear grilles through Barnham, including at the Trading Post and our pumps at Felpham are running to reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 11:00 20/11/2022.

The River Arun remains high but has fallen from its peak in Pulborough. Minor flood impacts may continue to affect the A29 at Pulborough, and could affect properties on Lower Street and Swan Corner, Pulborough, near to Swan Bridge and Bridge Cottages, Greatham. Minor flood impacts could also affect properties near Houghton Bridge, Amberley and may approach riverside properties, including near St Edmunds Cottage, Houghton. In Arundel, only minimal flood impacts are expected. Very little rain is forecast Saturday. However, the river is unlikely to return to a normal level until next week. Some roads, including the A29 at Pulborough, may remain impassable, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. Another 10-40mm of rain Sunday and Monday could cause more flood risk next week. Please keep flood protection products installed in Pulborough, Amberley and Arundel, if you have them. Our pumps in Pulborough are running to help reduce the risk of flooding.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 8.92 m and is stable.

The drain level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 7.13m and is rising by approximately 11mm 

Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this level exceeds 7.3 m, the road from Muchelney to Long load if this level exceeds 7.86 and the road from Muchelney to Thorney if this level exceeds 7.93 m. Property flooding is possible if this level exceeds 8.35 m.

Pumping will begin at Episcopi pumping station when levels in the river allow.

Dry weather is forecast for today Thursday, 17/11/2022, with the risk of isolated showers.

The River Yeo at Muchelney is forecast to remain stable

We are closely monitoring the situation.   
  
This message will be updated at 12:00 on Friday, 18/11/2022.

items.description: Tidal River Ouse from Naburn Lock to Selby
items.message: River Ouse levels remain high due to prolonged rainfall on 17/11/2022. Flooding is expected at riverside footpaths and low-lying land in York and Naburn, particularly around Naburn Lock. We have issued a flood warning for Naburn Lock. River levels in York peaked overnight on Friday evening at approximately 3.3m and are now falling slowly. The Ouse level at York Viking Recorder is currently just below 3.2m and is forecast to continue to fall slowly over the next 24 hours. River levels will remain high downstream of Naburn and within washlands throughout the weekend. Friday and Saturday are expected to be largely dry days; however, levels will remain high as the water makes its way down from the upper catchments. Tidal levels are not currently of concern. Further rainfall is expected from Sunday and river levels will remain high even if they fall slightly over the weekend. We are closing riverside flood gates in York. The Foss Barrier is in operation. Do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 9:00 PM on 19/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ouse, Burdyke, Holgate Beck, Blue Beck, River Foss, The Fleet

items.message: River levels remain high on the River Ouse due to prolonged rainfall on Thursday, 17/11/2022. Flooding is expected at riverside footpaths and low-lying land in York and to the south as far as Naburn Lock, including Kings Staith, Queens Staith and South Esplanade from Friday morning, 18/11/2022. River levels in York peaked overnight on Friday evening at approximately 3.3m and are slowly falling. The current Ouse level at York Viking Recorder is just below 3.2m, and is forecast to continue to fall slowly. Despite scattered showers over the weekend and into Monday, river levels are forecast to continue to fall slowly over the next 24 hours. However, levels will remain high as the water makes its way down from the upper catchments.  Further rainfall is then expected on Sunday and Monday and levels will fluctuate. We are closing riverside flood gates in York and the Foss Barrier is in operation managing flows on the River Foss. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 9:00 PM on 19/11/2022, or as the situation changes.
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.

items.description: River Ouse at York - St George's Field and Queen's Staith
items.message: River Ouse levels remain high due to persistent rainfall on 17/11/2022. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Ouse, including areas around properties along Queen's Staith, on South Esplanade, Friars Terrace and Tower Place, St George's Field carpark and Rowntree Park. Flooding is expected in these riverside areas through York from Friday morning, 18/11/2022 and over the weekend. River levels in York peaked overnight on Friday evening at approximately 3.3m and are slowly falling. The current Ouse level at York Viking Recorder is just below 3.2m, and forecast to continue to fall slowly. Despite scattered showers over the weekend and into Monday, river levels are forecast to continue to fall slowly over the next 24 hours. Levels will remain high as water makes its way down from the upper catchments. We are closing riverside flood gates in York. The Foss Barrier is in operation and managing River Foss flows. Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences. This message will be updated by 9:00 PM on 19/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ouse at York - riverside properties
items.message: River Ouse levels remain high due to persistent rainfall on 17/11/2022. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Ouse, including low lying land, particularly around properties on King's Staith in York and riverside areas through York from Lendall Bridge to Millennium Bridge. Flooding is expected in these riverside areas through York from Friday morning, 18/11/2022 and over the weekend. River levels in York peaked overnight on Friday evening at approximately 3.3m and are slowly falling. The current Ouse level at York Viking Recorder is just below 3.2m, and is forecast to continue to fall slowly. Despite scattered showers over the weekend and into Monday, river levels are forecast to fall slowly over the next 24 hours. Levels remain high as the water makes its way down from the upper catchments. We are closing riverside flood gates in York. The Foss Barrier is in operation and managing River Foss flows. Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences. This message will be updated by 9:00 PM on 19/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high on the River Ouse due to persistent rainfall on Thursday, 17/11/2022. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Ouse, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around Naburn Lock Buildings and Lock Cottages. Flooding is expected in these riverside areas from Friday morning, 18/11/2022 and over the weekend. River levels in York peaked overnight on Friday evening at approximately 3.3m, and at Naburn on Saturday morning. The current Ouse level at York Viking Recorder is just below 3.2m. Further scattered showers are forecast over the weekend and into Monday; however, river levels are forecast to continue to fall slowly over the next 24 hours. River levels will remain high as the water makes its way down from the upper catchments. We are closing riverside flood gates in York. The Foss Barrier is in operation. Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences. Do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 9:00 PM on 19/11/2022 or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Swale, Cod Beck, Bedale Beck

items.message: There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.

items.description: River Ure at Roecliffe Caravan Park
items.message: The Flood Warning has now been removed. However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding of roads and low lying land is still possible.

items.description: River Wreake for mills at Hoby, Thrussington and Ratcliffe
items.message:
River levels remain high but are falling at the Frisby river gauge as a result of the recent heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  
Areas most at risk are Thrussington Mill, including Station Road, and isolated properties at Hobee.   
Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours.  River levels have peaked and beginning to fall but still pose a flood risk.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Please avoid contact with flood water.
  
This message will be updated this afternoon, 19/11/22, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Warning has been removed. River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. There is no longer a threat of property flooding, but a Flood Alert remains in force for low-lying land and roads. No further significant rainfall is forecast. We continue to monitor the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire
floodArea.riverOrSea: River Derwent, Sea Cut, River Hertford, Burniston Beck

items.message: River levels remain high on the River Derwent due to prolonged rainfall over the last few days. Flooding remains possible in locations near the River Derwent, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around the Upper Derwent and Scarborough areas, including land around the Sea Cut at Scalby, Throxenby Beck, Old Malton, and Priorpot Beck in Norton through the weekend. No further significant rainfall is forecast today; however, levels will remain high over the weekend. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 09:00 PM on 19/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire, York

items.message: River levels remain high on the River Derwent due to prolonged rainfall over the last few days. Flooding remains possible in locations near the River Derwent, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around local roads and low-lying land around Buttercrambe, Stamford Bridge, Pocklington, Wressle, Wilberfoss and Elvington through the weekend. No further significant rainfall is forecast today, but river levels will remain high over the weekend. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 09:00 PM on 19/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours but we do not expect this to have a significant impact on river levels.   
We continue to monitor the situation.

This Flood Alert has been removed. 
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  Today is forecast to be mainly dry but further rainfall is currently forecast on Sunday and Monday.  
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this flood alert if necessary.
Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels and see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.

items.description: River Thames for the Abingdon area
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are still rising slowly on the River Thames as a result of the recent rainfall. Therefore, the risk of flooding of roads and farmland remains today 19/11/22, especially in the Abingdon area. 
Today is forecast to be mainly dry but further rainfall is currently forecast on Sunday and Monday. We expect river levels to remain high today and overnight.
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels and see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast. 
This message will be updated this evening, 19/11/22, or as the situation changes.
